entry.title: Building a Compelling S/4HANA Business Case: Beyond the Technical Upgrade
entry.content:
Preparing a robust business case for an SAP S/4HANA implementation is beyond a technical assessment. It is a strategic exercise aimed to define the organisation’s digital future. The move to SAP S/4HANA is considered a full scale transformation which requires considerations across organisation strategy, technology and financial viability. This blog is oriented to highlight critical aspects to be considered to build a compelling and approvable business case.

Strategic Alignment: “Why Now”: 

The foundation of the business case requires clear articulation of how SAP S/4HANA will directly support and accelerate the business strategy. This has to go beyond replacing the ageing SAP ECC system.

  • Alignment with the business goals: Identify / Define the organisation’s key strategic objectives – whether its increasing market share, effective cost management, building a resilient supply chain or to shift to a cloud first model. Map how SAP S/4HANA capabilities (e.g. process standardisation, embedded AI, embedded analytics, etc.) to these strategic objectives to demonstrate its necessity
  • Urgency Assessment: Define the “Why Now” This could be the result of the need for an agile solution to meet the competitive pressures of the industry, ability to quickly integrate acquisitions or to replace a complex and costly SAP ECC solution.
  • Cloud Operating Model: The decision is tied to a cloud strategy. Evaluate your chosen Cloud Operating Model (SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud or Private Cloud or Sovereign Cloud). This decision has implications from a licensing, TCO, agility and governance of the target state. The business case must justify the chosen model based on factors like standardisation, required functionality and regulatory compliance.
  • Embedded AI and Intelligence: SAP S/4HANA is the core of the intelligent enterprise. The business case needs to proactively identify and quantify the value of embedded AI and process automation opportunities. This is a important consideration for definition of a target state and directly linked to the business benefits like productivity improvements, enhanced user experience and better decision making

Strategic Fit - Figure 1

Option Identification and Selection Criteria:

A credible business case must evaluate all the viable options to develop a proposed path bearing in mind the target state and not just the replacement of a single solution.

  • Identification of options:
    • Option 0: Do nothing: This will be the baseline for comparing any other options. However, there will be risks and costs associated with not moving both from a business and technology viewpoint. Ensure that they are highlighted within the business case
    • Option 1: Brownfield: Focused on technical migration of SAP ECC with SAP S/4HANA while retaining existing business processes and customisations. The option will require to incorporate the mandatory changes required as a result of the move to SAP S/4HANA, but it could also help to deliver minimal business benefits through improved UI and better analytics.
    • Option 2: Greenfield Implementation: An implementation approach focused on adoption of out of box capabilities and aligned with Clean Core Extensibility Framework
    • Option 3: Selective Data Transition: A hybrid approach between greenfield and brownfield oriented out of functional or geographic dependencies and business priorities
  • Selection and Ranking of Decision Criteria: Establish evaluation / decision making criteria to objectively compare the options under consideration. The criteria should be informed by strategic objectives, architecture principles and business priorities. Recommendation would be to use a weighted scoring matric to objectively assess the options. Some of the criteria which should be part of any business case are highlighted below:
    • Strategic Fit: Alignment with the strategic goals and future scalabiloty
    • Total Cost of Ownership: NPV, IRR and payback period over a 5-10 year period
    • Business Value: Quantitative and qualitative business benefits, generally against key performance indicators across critical business processes.
    • Time to Value: Speed of deployment and flexibility to adopt to change.
    • Risk Assessment: Commercial, Technical and Change Management risks

Cost Benefit Analysis - Figure 2

 

Target State Definition and Deployment Roadmap

This is the final section of the business case where the selected option is translated to a plan. It should be indicative of the link between the effort and the delivered business value.

  • Target State Architecture: Define a target state architecture aligned with the SAP strategy. It should clearly separate the digital core from other SAP and non SAP applications within the landscape. It should highlight the use of Clean Core by building extensions on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). This is a critical aspect of the architecture definition as it highlights readiness for future upgrades and TCO reduction. It should also highlight other critical components like data, security, analytics and infrastructure management.
  • Deployment Roadmap and Value Realisation: Develop a phased deployment roadmap leveraging the SAP Activate Methodology. SAP offers Activate methodologies for each of the transition options described above.
    • Roadmap should be broken down into clear project phases linked with key delivery milestones
    • Roadmap should be value driven. Develop architecture building blocks which will deliver the business value as well as consider the business and technology dependencies as part of the target state
    • Clear indication of the expected business value that will be realised across the different phases. This would link the project expenditure to the expected returns
  • Risk and Change Management: A specific section should be captured within the business case identifying the risks and the mitigation approaches. The risks could range from an organisation perspective, delivery perspective or technical perspective. Common examples include scope change, gap resolution or resource constraints). The plan should also highlight a well considered change management strategy to establish a clear communication plan and to ensure user adoption.

Deployment Roadmap - Figure 3

 

A well-constructed business case is a key instrument to mobilise the transformation, aligning the technical execution with strategic initiatives and clearly defined path to achieve business value. SAP Business Transformation and Advisory team within can assist you with the development of detailed business case for your SAP S/4HANA implementation.

Please feel to reach out to me for any more information.

entry.title: Understanding the UI5 Component Loading Error in CLM Fiori Apps
entry.content:
Sometimes you open a Fiori app and it stops right away. Instead of the usual screen, you get a message saying the UI5 component couldn’t be loaded. I’ve seen customers raise incidents about this in CLM apps like Cash Flow Analyzer, but the reason isn’t specific to CLM.

In most cases, the browser just can’t load one required file, and that’s enough for the whole app to fail. Once you know what causes it, the fix is straightforward.

What the user sees

You click the tile, and the launchpad throws this message:
App could not be opened because the SAP UI5 component of the application could not be loaded.

Fiori Launchpad showing error

If you check the browser console, the system gives a more direct hint:
Failed to load UI5 component for navigation intent

For a CLM app like Cash Flow Analyzer, it may point to a specific file that couldn’t be loaded:
failed to load 'fin/cash/flow/analyzer/Component.js' from /sap/bc/ui5_ui5/sap/fin_flowanalyze/... 403 - Forbidden

Customers have reported this issue, and since I work with Cash and Liquidity Management apps, I see these cases as well. But the cause itself is not tied to CLM. It’s a basic UI5 loading issue that can happen with any Fiori app.

What’s actually happening

Every Fiori app needs its UI5 component to be reachable through an active ICF service. If that ICF node is inactive, the system blocks the request with a 403 – Forbidden. The browser can’t load Component.js, and the app stops immediately.

The navigation intent tells the system which UI5 component to load. If the ICF node linked to that component is inactive after a system refresh, transport, or upgrade, the loading process ends right there.

Nothing else can continue until the service is active again.

A simple CLM example: Cash Flow Analyzer

In the Fiori apps reference library, Cash Flow Analyzer shows the UI5 component details along with the ICF path it depends on.
App reference library showing the ICF path
Open SICF, search for the service path of your Fiori app, and verify its status.
SICF Transaction
If the service is inactive, the path appears grey. This is usually the reason the browser can’t reach the UI5 component at runtime.
Inactive service
Activate the service, run the test again, and the app should load unless something else is missing upstream.

Node after activation

Why this helps

Knowing this check saves time. Before looking into authorizations or configuration, you can verify whether the system is even able to load the UI5 component. It’s a quick step that avoids unnecessary back-and-forth and helps users troubleshoot more confidently.

Closing thoughts

If you often work with CLM or other Fiori apps, it helps to compare the app reference library with what you see in SICF. Once you understand how they connect, this error becomes much easier to solve.

entry.title: Enhancing Migration Efficiency Through Controlled SUM DMO Table Splitting
entry.content:
Understanding Table Splitting in SUM DMO

In a DMO or Downtime Optimized DMO (doDMO) scenario, application table transfer occurs across specific SUM phases:

  • EU_CLONE_CP2STAB_RUN – Uptime phase (DMO & doDMO)

  • EU_CLONE_MIG_OPTDMO_INI_RUN – Uptime phase (doDMO only)

  • EU_CLONE_MIG_DT_RUN – Downtime phase (DMO & doDMO)

The preparation and calculation of table split logic occurs in corresponding preparation phases, all of which operate during uptime. This design allows proactive configuration before the critical migration execution begins.

While standard SUM behavior is sufficient for most systems, extremely large tables may require enforced customization to ensure balanced workload distribution and better utilization of parallel R3load processes.

Real-Time Issue Faced

During S4HANA upgrade with migration, a large tables like BALDAT with table size of 150GB and other tables with large size consuming excessive time in the table splitting phase. 

As a result, SUM extended runtime and this behavior directly contributed to increased downtime (i.e. 28Hrs27mins) risk and inefficient resource utilization.

 

Strategic Intervention Applied

Instead of relying solely on default parameters, we introduced controlled overrides in SUM configuration files to optimize splitting behavior.

Table-Specific Custom Splitting

We explicitly defined split fields by creating the following configuration file:

<SUM_DIR>/abap/control/EUCLONEDEFS_ADD.LST
And added as shown in below screenshot.

Syntax used:

Inhibit splitting of a table:
<TABLENAME> nosplit
Split a table into a defined number of segments:
<TABLENAME> segmentsize=0.02
Note: The segmentsize value is calculated as 1 / <number_of_splits>.
For example, 0.02 represents 50 segments for the table.

This ensured SUM enforced controlled segmentation of the table into predefined buckets, enabling predictable workload distribution and stable split calculation behavior.

 

Results Achieved

Following this intervention:

  • Large tables were processed in controlled parallel segments

  • SUM phases stabilized significantly

  • Overall downtime reduced measurably compared to earlier dry runs

  • Resource utilization became more balanced and predictable

This strategic tweaking allowed us to ensure smoother system availability and meet strict business downtime SLAs.

Downtime without table splitting took 28Hrs27mins

Downtime with table splitting took 12Hrs27mins

 

Key Takeaways

  • SUM default behavior is reliable but may not suit extreme data volumes.

  • Manual parameter tuning should only be performed by experienced SAP consultants.

  • Real-time log analysis is essential to identify root causes in splitting failures.

  • Controlled split field definition can resolve non-ASCII and key field selectivity issues.

  • Optimized parallelism improves both uptime processing and downtime efficiency.

 

Conclusion

This experience highlights how intelligent optimization of SAP SUM table splitting can play a crucial role in achieving successful S/4HANA upgrades. By leveraging advanced configuration parameters responsibly, we transformed a potential bottleneck into a controlled and efficient migration process.

For consultants handling large-scale systems with high-volume tables, understanding and applying these optimizations can be the difference between extended outages and seamless transitions.

 

Reference

This implementation approach is aligned with guidance from SAP Note 3386079 – SUM DMO scenarios: Manual Options for Table Splitting and Table Migration, which provides expert-level control options for influencing SUM table splitting and migration behavior.

entry.title: Aufbau einer Key-User-Community im SAP S/4HANA-Projekt bei Aalberts hydronic flow control
entry.content:
Kathleen Regener berichtet über den Aufbau einer Key-User-Community in einem internationalen S/4HANA-Projekt. Die zentrale Erkenntnis: Eine Community braucht mehr als nur Infrastruktur – sie braucht den richtigen Zeitpunkt, aktive Moderation und Key-User, die etwas Greifbares haben, um sich beteiligen zu können.

Über das Projekt und die Ausgangssituation

Kathleen Regener, PMO und Lead Change Management bei Aalberts hydronic flow control, berichtete in der SAP Training und Change Kaffee-Ecke über den Aufbau einer Key-User-Community im Rahmen der konzernweiten S/4HANA-Transformation. Das Unternehmen bietet ganzheitliche Lösungen für Heiz-, Kühl- und Sanitärsysteme in Gebäuden an. Das Projekt umfasst die Ablösung von 6 verschiedenen ERP-Systemen für insgesamt 800 Enduser.

Die Besonderheit: Die Key-User wurden nicht ausgewählt, sondern konnten sich für das Projekt bewerben. Am Ende konnten über 100 motivierte Key-User gewonnen werden, die die Änderungen mittragen wollten. Diese wurden in lokale Key-User und Power User aufgeteilt. Die lokalen Key-User waren die Ansprechpartner für das Projektteam und wurden für ihre Rolle freigestellt. Die Power User unterstützten nach verfügbarer Zeit.

Struktur der Key-User-Community

Das Projektteam bestand aus Domain Process Ownern (DPOs), Technical Process Ownern (TPOs) und den Key-Usern. Für die Global Template Phase wurden zusätzlich Global Key-User aus den Niederlanden, Deutschland und Frankreich eingebunden, die in die Workstreams Warehouse, Sales, Production, Supply Chain und Finance aufgeteilt waren.

Abbildung 1: Struktur des Projektteams mit DPOs, TPOs, Key-Usern (Global und lokal) und Power Usern

Projektphasen und Rollout-Strategie

Nach der Template-Phase wurden die Global Key-User zu lokalen Key-Usern und im ersten Rollout in den Niederlanden und UK eingesetzt. Die übrigen Key-User gingen in eine Projektpause.

Diese Projektpause warf zentrale Fragen auf:

  • Wie bleibt man mit allen in Kontakt?
  • Wie können die Key-User zu einem Team zusammenwachsen?
  • Wie können wir sicherstellen, dass wir alle relevanten Informationen mit allen teilen?
  • Wie teilt man Lessons Learned aus den einzelnen Waves?

Aufbau der Community-Infrastruktur

Die Entscheidung fiel auf den Aufbau einer Teams-basierten Community mit verschiedenen Kanälen. Der Start erfolgte mit einem offiziellen Kick-Off für alle Key-User. Es wurde eine Hausordnung erstellt, die das Verhalten in der Community regelte. Die Key-User erhielten eine Teams-Schulung, um die Umgebung optimal nutzen zu können.

Inhalte der Key-User-Community

Die Community bot ein umfassendes Angebot:

Workshop-Unterlagen:

  • Stressmanagement
  • Umgang mit Widerständen
  • Train-the-Trainer-Unterlagen

Dokumentationen:

  • Quick Reference Cards
  • Projekt- und SAP-Glossar
  • FAQ zu Projekt und S/4HANA
  • Rollenbeschreibungen

Kommunikation und Austausch:

  • Raum für Fragen
  • Raum für Erfolgsstories
  • Raum für Lessons Learned
  • Projektinformationen und Timeline
  • Zentraler Meeting Hub
  • Regelmäßige Communication Starter

Ein Feedback-Channel wurde eingerichtet. Fragen wurden so beantwortet, dass die Antworten für alle Key-User sinnvoll nutzbar waren und im gesamten Team geteilt wurden.

Herausforderungen in der Praxis

Trotz der umfassender Vorbereitung gestaltete sich der Start schwierig. Die Reaktionen auf Communication Starter beschränkten sich meist auf ein Daumen-hoch. Nach einem halben Jahr lautete das Fazit: Wir hatten keine Community, sondern ein Publikum. Die Informationen wurden aufgenommen, aber es fand keine wirkliche Interaktion statt.

Die neun zentralen Herausforderungen

Kathleen identifizierte neun konkrete Herausforderungen:

  • Keine Reaktionen der Key-User an uns als Change Management
  • Doppelrolle (Projekt und Tagesgeschäft) führte zu Zeitproblemen bei Key Usern
  • Die Community hat nicht gelebt - es gab keine echte Interaktion
  • Unsicherheit beim Teilen: Key-User aus Wave 1 wussten nicht, was sie mit anderen Key-Usern teilen können
  • Fehlende Fragestellung: Key-User aus inaktiven Waves wussten nicht, was sie fragen können
  • Projektinformationen konnten nicht geteilt werden, da teilweise noch keine Entscheidungen getroffen waren oder das System noch nicht fertig war
  • Regelmäßige Check-Ins wurden nicht genutzt, da sich Key-User noch nicht vom Projekt betroffen fühlten
  • Unterschiedliches Onboarding von Key-Usern und Power Usern
  • Geringe Teilnahmequote an Umfragen

Die zentrale Erkenntnis war: Der Zeitpunkt für den Aufbau der Community war falsch gewählt.

Lessons Learned und Anpassungen

Eine Umfrage zeigte, dass die Key-User Beispiele, Tipps und Best Practices wollten, ihnen aber nicht bewusst war, dass sie selbst Input liefern müssten. Das Selbstbewusstsein, selbst zur Community beitragen zu können, fehlte.

Konkrete Anpassungen in Wave 2

Abbildung: Change Management Lessons Learned und implementierte Verbesserungen

Das Change Management implementierte acht zentrale Verbesserungen:

  1. Onboarding-Phase und Toolkit für Key-User der nächsten Wave
  • Alle betroffenen lokalen Key-User und Power User wurden zum Kick-Off eingeladen
  • Gebündelte Informationen in Landessprache
  • Hausaufgaben und Systemzugriff für die Vorbereitungsphase
  1. Statt Umfragen für Lessons Learned → feste Termine für Feedback
  • Gezielte Fragen in persönlichen Terminen
  • Mehr direktes Feedback
  1. Erhöhung der Kommunikationsfrequenz
  • Zwei bis drei Communication Starter pro Woche
  • Mehr Bewegung in der Community
  1. Auf Wunsch: Aufnahme der DPOs und TPOs
  • Mehr Sicherheit für Key-User
  • Direkter Zugang zu Entscheidungsträgern
  1. Bi-weekly Community Meeting → monatliches Meeting
  • Nur für Key-User der aktuellen Wave
  • In Landessprache
  • Mit Vorab-Fragen über den Feedback-Kanal
  1. Einführung des Projekt-Glossars
  • Besseres Verständnis für pausierte Key-User
  • Einheitliche Sprache im Projekt
  1. Anpassung/Trennung der einzelnen Umfragen
  • Wave-bezogene Umfragen
  • Angepasst an die jeweilige Projektphase
  1. Buddy-System für Key-User aus Wave 1 und 2
  • Erfahrene Key-User unterstützen neue Key-User
  • Über Teams-Tag-Funktion organisiert
  • Austausch bleibt sichtbar für andere

Schulung und Training

Die Key-User wurden in zwei Schienen geschult: im Systembereich und vom Change Management im Bereich Trainingsgestaltung, Umgang mit Widerständen und Umgang mit Endusern. Die Schulungsunterlagen waren Aufgabe der Key-User, wurden aber von den DPOs reviewed. Enduser wurden einbezogen, um zu prüfen, ob das Level für gute Schulungen erreicht wurde.

Die Enduser-Trainings werden von den Key-Usern geplant und durchgeführt. Die Key-User stehen nach dem Go-Live als Hypercare-Support zur Verfügung und sind danach erste Ansprechpartner für die Enduser. Die Trainingsunterlagen werden auf einer Enduser-SharePoint-Seite für alle zugänglich abgelegt und sind über SAP Enable Now nachträglich verfügbar.

Bei der Trainingsplanung durften die Key-User die Gruppengröße selbst festlegen, was zu mehr Wohlbefinden führte. Es wurden Dry Runs veranstaltet, bei denen die Key-User ihre Classroom-Trainings vor dem Projektteam vorführen und Feedback erhalten konnten. Templates wurden bereitgestellt, um die Key-User zu entlasten.

Rolle des Change Managements

Das Change Management wurde erst mit diesem Projekt aufgebaut. Intern lastet die Arbeit auf einer Person (=Kathleen), unterstützt von drei Personen eines Implementierungspartners. Ein Community Lead aus den Key-Usern war geplant, konnte aber aufgrund von Zeitmangel nicht umgesetzt werden. Das Change Management übernahm daher wieder die Moderation.

Die Kommunikation an das Management war wichtig, um sicherzustellen, dass die Key-User Zeit für ihre Projektarbeit bekommen und nicht mit 150 Prozent belastet werden. Das Change Management nutzte SAP Enable Now für die Erstellung von Lernpfaden für neue Kollegen um das Onboarding optimal vorzubereiten.

Erkenntnisse aus der Diskussion in der Community Session

Die Teilnehmenden an der Session teilten zahlreiche eigene Erfahrungen. Häufig genannte Herausforderungen waren Überlastung der Key-User, Sprachbarrieren, regionale Arbeitsweisen, uneinheitliche Anforderungen und fehlende Ressourcen.

Was funktioniert in der Praxis?

Formate für erfolgreiche Communities:

  • Präsenztreffen und direkter Austausch
  • Zwei Stunden Treffen alle zwei Wochen mit der Projektleitung
  • Zweimal monatlich eine Stunde via Teams
  • Subgruppen nach Lokationen
  • Regelmäßige Calls mit fester Agenda
  • Moderierte Online-Plattformen
  • Informelle Treffen wie Kaffeeroulette

Unterstützungsmaßnahmen:

  • Train-the-Trainer-Seminare
  • Change-Management-Trainings
  • Konfliktmanagement-Training
  • Ambassador-Netzwerke
  • Templates für Schulungsunterlagen
  • Dry Runs mit Feedback
  • Tandem-Ansätze bei ersten Schulungen
  • Zusätzliche Testressourcen

Engagement fördern – denn Engagement ist eine der großen Herausforderungen in Communities:

  • Niedrigschwellige Formate wie Polls
  • Belohnungen für Key-User wie Special Events
  • In manchen Fällen monetäre Anreize
  • Lessons-Learned-Sessions
  • Gemeinsame Retrospektiven
  • Social Events – feiern von Erfolgen

Innovative Ansätze:

  • Kaffeeroulette über Teams: Zwei bis drei User werden per Zufall für eine Viertelstunde zusammengeführt
  • Networking Lunch mit Matching nach Interessen
  • Themenvorschläge für informelle Treffen

Konkrete Tipps für die Praxis von Key-User Netzwerken

Auch wenn es nun evtl. Dopplungen gibt versuche ich hier nochmals Tips von Kathleen sowie den vielen Community Teilnehmenden hier aufzuführen. 

Timing und Planung

Timing beachten: Den richtigen Zeitpunkt für den Community-Start wählen. Key-User brauchen etwas Greifbares, um sich beteiligen zu können.

Einheitliches Onboarding: Alle Key-User-Gruppen von Anfang an gleich abholen, um unterschiedliche Wissensstände zu vermeiden.

Wave-bezogene Planung: Umfragen und Meetings an die jeweilige Projektphase anpassen.

Kommunikation und Moderation

Aktive Moderation: Communities brauchen aktive Moderation und regelmäßige Impulse. Communication Starter allein reichen nicht.

Kommunikationsfrequenz erhöhen: Zwei bis drei Impulse pro Woche setzen, um Bewegung in die Community zu bringen.

Management einbinden: Führungskräfte über den Zeitbedarf der Key-User informieren.

Sprache und Verständnis

Sprache anpassen: Bei internationalen Projekten Meetings und Unterlagen in Landessprache anbieten.

Technische Hilfsmittel nutzen: MS Teams mit Co-Pilot und Teams Professional für Übersetzungen nutzen.

Glossar erstellen: Sicherstellen, dass alle in einer Sprache sprechen durch ein Projekt-Glossar.

Entlastung und Unterstützung

Entlastung schaffen: Key-User durch Templates, Dry Runs, Tandem-Ansätze und zusätzliche Ressourcen (z.B. beim Testen) aktiv unterstützen.

Didaktische Unterstützung: Power User oder Autoren unterstützen bei der Unterlagenerstellung.

Backfill organisieren: Neue Mitarbeitende einstellen oder interne Umverteilung für Daily Business.

Formate und Tools

Präsenz ermöglichen: Wo möglich, Präsenztreffen oder zumindest regelmäßige Online-Meetings mit fester Agenda organisieren.

Buddy-Systeme nutzen: Erfahrene Key-User mit neuen Key-Usern vernetzen.

Tool-Wahl: Abhängig von Kommunikationsgewohnheiten im Unternehmen (Teams, Slack, SharePoint).

Subgruppen bilden: Nach Lokationen, Workstreams oder Waves organisieren.

Erwartungsmanagement

Erwartungen managen: Nicht erwarten, dass alle aktiv mitmachen. In Communities sind oft nur ein bis zwei Prozent wirklich aktiv.

Publikum vs. Community: Verstehen, dass Community-Bildung Zeit braucht.

Zusammenfassung

Der Aufbau einer Key-User-Community in einem internationalen S/4HANA-Projekt ist komplex und braucht Zeit. Die initiale Infrastruktur allein reicht nicht aus. Key-User befinden sich in einer Doppelrolle zwischen Daily Business und Projekt und brauchen aktive Unterstützung, klare Strukturen und das Gefühl, nicht allein zu sein.

Entscheidend ist, Key-User nicht zu überfordern, sondern durch Templates, Schulungen und Tandem-Ansätze zu entlasten. Sprachbarrieren und unterschiedliche Wissensstände sollten aktiv adressiert werden. Der richtige Zeitpunkt für den Community-Start ist wichtig. Key-User brauchen etwas Konkretes, um sich beteiligen zu können.

Die Anpassungen in Wave 2 zeigten Wirkung: einheitliches Onboarding, höhere Kommunikationsfrequenz, Meetings in Landessprache, Buddy-Systeme und die Einbindung der DPOs und TPOs.

Change Management ist kein Nice-to-have, sondern essenziell für den Projekterfolg. Die Erkenntnis, dass viele Herausforderungen trotz unterschiedlicher Branchen ähnlich sind, zeigt uns auch wieder den Wert des Austauschs in der Community.

Weiterführende Links und Ressourcen

SAP Community

  • SAP Training and Change Management Community
  • Dokumentation der Kaffee-Ecke Sessions und nächster Termin

Kommende Sessions

  • Walk Me Praxisbeispiel - Webinar mit Stada (12/2025) / Walk Me Learning Arc - Infosession zur Learning Komponente (Januar 2026) / Enable Now zu Walk Me Transition - Roundtable (Februar 2026) – Infos und Anmeldung hier
  • Kaffee-Ecke – Change & Training Retrospektive 2025/ Ausblick 2026 - 18.12.2025

Über die Kaffee-Ecke: Die SAP Training and Change Management Kaffee-Ecke ist eine monatliche Community Session, die jeden dritten Donnerstag im Monat stattfindet. Sie bietet Raum für Austausch, Good Practices und Lessons Learned rund um Training, Learning und Change Management in SAP-Projekten.

entry.title: BP user exits to check data before saving (SAP GUI transaction for Business Partners)
entry.content:
I've read a few questions and answers about which user exit to choose to add custom checks before saving in the SAP GUI transaction BP (maintenance of business partners), but without understanding which ones to choose, how they are all related, what they exactly do. I'm trying here to provide an overview of what I have quickly understood.

I'm running S/4HANA 2023 FPS 1 (ABAP 7.58 SP 1).

In short, there are these user exits, called sequentially:

  • the BP checks by the BDT framework (Business Data Toolset),
  • the BP checks by the BAdI BUPA_FURTHER_CHECKS,
  • the vendor or customer specific checks by the BAdI VENDOR_EXTENSION_CHECK and CUSTOMER_EXTENSION_CHECK.
  • NB: if I understand well, S/4HANA has merged customer and vendor maintenance into BP, and before S/4HANA, there were specific vendor and customer user exits (not part of BP) which were the Business Transaction Events 1340 and 1440 and the BAdI CUSTOMER_ADD_DATA and VENDOR_ADD_DATA, method CHECK_ALL_DATA. I don't discuss them here.

In BP, the BDT checks are first called. You may create your own function module (no parameters) and add it to the transaction code BUS7 for the event DCHCK. For the sequence number, you may enter any two last characters (positions 6 and 7) other than "00" (double zero), because the positions are reserved for custom use, as explained in the SAP Help Portal:

  • Naming convention: The position number has 7 places. Each development stage has one place of its own. The places from the left up to your own place are freely assignable. The application uses them to determine the position of the view within a section in relation to the views of the upstream development stages. The numbers to the right of your own place must be ‘0’.
  • The following places are reserved for the development stages:
  • Application basis 1+2
  • Standard applications 3
  • Industry applications 4
  • Development partners 5
  • Customers (central) 6
  • Customers (branch) 7

Then, the method CHECK_CENTRAL of the Classic BAdI BUPA_FURTHER_CHECKS is called. You may also implement it (transaction code SE18, menu Implementations > Create). This method receives few parameters (table BUT000, name, organization data, person data). If you need other data from the business partner, you may call function modules like BUP_BUPA_BUT0IS_GET (table BUT0IS being the industry sectors defined at the BP level) to get the data modified (or not) by the user, before the data is really saved to the database.

After that, if the partner is of type vendor, BP calls the method CHECK of the BAdI Definition VENDOR_EXTENSION_CHECK of the Enhancement Spot VENDOR_EXTENSION.

If the partner of type customer, BP calls the method CHECK of the BAdI Definition CUSTOMER_EXTENSION_CHECK of the Enhancement Spot CUSTOMER_EXTENSION.

The two BAdI above receive only the vendor or customer specific data, not the whole business partner data, to prevent saving the data to the vendor or customer specific tables LFA1, KNA1 (and so on), but even if an error is raised by the user exit, the business partner data is saved.

In my case, I wanted to define a blocking check on BP data, the most simple way, so I used the classic BAdI BUPA_FURTHER_CHECKS.

For information, if you want to know about how the vendor or customer specific data is filtered out from the business partner data, it's done by the class CVI_STRATEGY_BP_VENDOR, in the method IF_MDS_CTRL_STRATEGY_IMPL~PROCESS.

I don't know how exactly the BP customizing decides how to display the vendor or customer data, and how it's saved into the tables LFA1, KNA1, etc. What I could understand:

  1. If you create a Business Partner, you choose a partner group from the table TB000 (e.g. PCUS, PVEN)
  2. The SPRO activity "Define partner role from client to partner" (SM30 > CVIV_CUST_TO_BP2) assigns one or more partner roles (e.g. FLCU00) to the partner group (e.g. PCUS).
  3. The SPRO activity "Define partner role from vendor to partner" (SM30 > CVIV_VEND_TO_BP2) assigns one or more partner roles (e.g. FLVN00) to a partner group (e.g. PVEN).
  4. The SPRO activity "Define partner roles" (SM34 > BUPA_TB003) links the partner role (e.g. FLCU00) to the BDT partner view (e.g. FLCU00). This BDT partner view is defined in the transaction BUSD and is connected to Dynpro screens with ABAP logic. It's not clear to me how, from here, some BDT partner function modules are called at save time and how they write to either the table LFA1 (vendor) or KNA1 (customer).
  5. The SPRO activity "Assign partner role to client group" (V_TBD001) assigns a client group from KNA1-KTOKD (e.g. CUST) to a partner group (e.g. PCUS). This customizing indicates if the client number is the same as the partner number. For information, the relationship table is CVI_CUST_LINK.
  6. The SPRO activity "Assign partner role to vendor group" (V_TBC001) assigns a vendor group from LFA1-KTOKK (e.g. VEND) to a partner group (e.g. PVEN). This customizing indicates if the vendor number is the same as the partner number. For information, the relationship table is CVI_VEND_LINK.

If I've missed something, if I'm wrong or if you can enlighten me, please add a comment. I will then update this post.

Thank you for reading!

entry.title: How AI Solutions Can Align with SAP’s Clean Core Principles
entry.content:
“Clean core” and “Artificial Intelligence” are often discussed in isolation. Clean core is positioned to reduce technical debt and keep SAP S/4HANA upgradeable, while AI is usually associated with new workloads, additional components, and non-SAP technologies such as Python.

This separation leads to a common misconception: that AI solutions, especially those implemented in Python or using external models, are incompatible with a clean core strategy.

In practice, AI and clean core are closely aligned. SAP’s own definition of an ERP clean core emphasizes standardization, modern extensibility, and the ability to leverage reliable data and AI innovations on top of a stable core. When designed correctly, AI solutions can fully comply with clean core principles and in many cases help to realize the intended benefits of the strategy.

SAP Clean Core Strategy

SAP describes an ERP clean core strategy as a set of guiding principles to keep business critical systems agile, cost-effective, and ready to adopt innovation. Key elements include:

  • Reduction of historically grown complexity and custom code in the core ERP system.
  • Standardization of processes by staying close to SAP best practices.
  • Use of modern extensibility options, particularly side-by-side extensions on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).
  • API- first and event-driven integration, rather than direct database access.
  • Cloud readiness and continuous innovation, including the ability to exploit AI capabilities.

Clean core does not prohibit custom logic or non-ABAP technology. It defines where that logic should run (outside the S/4 core) and how it should integrate (through released, supported interfaces).

Principles Relevant for AI Solutions

For AI initiatives, the following clean core principles are particularly relevant:

  • Decoupled innovation: AI workloads should run outside the S/4HANA core, typically on SAP BTP, and consume data via published APIs or data services.
  • Use of official extensibility models: Extensions should follow the models described in SAP’s clean core and extensibility guidance, including in-app extensions, developer extensibility (ABAP Cloud), and side-by-side extensions.
  • API-first and event-driven patterns: AI components should use official APIs and events to interact with core applications, rather than relying on direct table access or modifications.
  • Governed data access: Data for AI models should be accessed through governed layers such as SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere, which preserve security, compliance and lineage.

If an AI architecture respects these principles, it is aligned with the clean core strategy, regardless of the programming language or specific AI framework used.

Clean-Core Compliant AI Architecture Patterns

Side-by-Side AI on SAP BTP

SAP’s “Generative AI on SAP BTP” reference architecture explicitly positions SAP BTP as the platform for AI workloads, with S/4HANA and other SAP cloud solutions used as systems of record.

In a side-by-side pattern:

  • SAP S/4HANA
    • Hosts standard business processes and transactional data.
    • Exposes business functionality via released OData/REST APIs and events.
  • SAP BTP (AI and application layer)
    • Runs AI workloads using SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad, where models and pipelines can be implemented in Python or other languages.
    • Uses SAP Generative AI Hub for LLM access, prompt orchestration, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and agentic scenarios.
  • Integration
    • Uses SAP Integration Suite, API Management and/or Event Mesh to connect AI components with S/4HANA through supported interfaces.

 

                       

AI workloads remain in the BTP extension layer, while SAP S/4HANA stays as the clean, standard core accessed via published APIs.

This pattern adheres to clean core because all custom AI logic and orchestration stay outside the S/4HANA core, while S/4HANA is accessed only via documented integration points.

AI Enabled Data Layer with SAP HANA Cloud

SAP has started using the term “AI enabled clean core with SAP HANA Cloud”, referring to architectures where S/4HANA remains the core ERP and SAP HANA Cloud provides an intelligent data layer for analytics and AI-driven applications.

Key characteristics:

  • Operational data is exposed or replicated from S/4HANA to SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere in a governed way.
  • AI models (classical ML or generative) are trained and executed against this data layer.
  • AI outputs are surfaced in side-by-side applications or written back into S/4HANA via APIs and standard extension points.

The core ERP remains clean and standard. AI driven logic is implemented in the surrounding data and application layers, which aligns with SAP’s stated goal of “increasing the pace of innovation and leveraging business value through reliable data and AI innovations” without compromising the core.

Programming Language and Clean Core Compliance

A frequent objection is that AI solutions are implemented in Python or with non-SAP frameworks and therefore cannot be reconciled with clean core.

From SAP’s standpoint, this is not correct. The clean core strategy focuses on minimizing custom code inside the core and using side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP to build new applications and innovations.

SAP’s own extensibility guidance explicitly acknowledges BTP side-by-side extensions implemented in ABAP Cloud, Java, Node.js and other languages. AI services developed in Python and deployed on SAP AI Core or container runtimes on BTP fall into exactly the same category.

Clean core compliance therefore depends on:

  • The location of the code (outside S/4HANA vs. in-core modifications).
  • The integration pattern (released APIs and events vs. direct table access).

It does not depend on whether the AI logic is written in ABAP, Python, Java or another language.

 

                                    

AI solutions built on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud surrounding a clean SAP S/4HANA core, with integration strictly via APIs and events.

 

SAP’s clean core strategy is often misunderstood as a constraint on innovation. It provides the architectural discipline required to adopt AI at scale without compromising the stability and upgradeability of SAP S/4HANA.

By:

  • keeping AI workloads on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud,
  • integrating through released APIs and events, and
  • applying SAP’s extensibility guidance consistently,

organizations can build advanced AI solutions that are fully aligned with clean core principles. The question is not whether AI is compatible with clean core, but whether AI architectures are designed to follow the same patterns that SAP itself recommends for any modern extension.

entry.title: The Next Level of Global Payments: SAP Unlocks Enhanced Cross-Border Capabilities with TransferMate
entry.content:
In an increasingly interconnected global economy, businesses need payment solutions that are fast, transparent, secure, and seamlessly integrated into their ERP systems. That’s why the newly announced partnership between SAP and TransferMate represents a major step forward for finance and treasury teams.

Through this partnership, TransferMate’s cross-border payment service is now integrated directly into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity as a non-bank payments provider bringing powerful and innovative global payment capabilities straight into SAP ERP solutions, including SAP Cloud ERP.

For organizations operating across multiple currencies and jurisdictions, this integration has the potential to significantly simplify international financial operations.

Traditionally, making international payments required organizations to juggle multiple banking partners, external platforms, or third-party portals. This fragmented processes introduced friction, increased operational risk, and added unnecessary costs that this partnership can solve

What You Can Expect from TransferMate’s integration into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity

- Fast, transparent and efficient international payments without leaving your ERP

  • No additional portals or manual steps; enjoy seamless straight-through processing.
  • Automated flows from SAP ERP directly to TransferMate payment infrastructure reducing errors, manual intervention, and operational risk.

- Reduced complexity and improved scalability

  • SAP users can send and receive funds globally through a the unified and standardized payment infrastructure from TransferMate.
  • A scalable payment solution that grows with organizations expanding their international footprint.

- Greater transparency and control

  • End-to-end visibility from cross border payment initiation to settlement
  • Enhanced liquidity management with better payment tracking and more payment options.

- Strengthened compliance and security

  • TransferMate operates a fully regulated global payments network, ensuring adherence to local and international financial regulations.

Who Can Benefit?

Any organization using SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity—regardless of whether they are running SAP ERP, SAP S/4HANA, or SAP Cloud ERP—can take advantage of this integration.

As companies continue to expand globally, the demand for frictionless, embedded financial tools will only grow. The integration of TransferMate into SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity marks a major step toward making global payments as simple, secure, and seamless as domestic transactions—directly from your SAP environment.

entry.title: S/4HANA 2023 FPS3 Fully-Activated Appliance standard installation
entry.content:
This blog covers installation of (1) SAP S/4HANA server and (2) SAP NW JAVA / ADS server as shown in the graphic below. The installation is based on file restore and is different from the standard installs using SWPM.

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for other blogs

In this blog the procedure is simplified for standard installation with NO HOSTNAME OR SID CHANGE. The advantage with this is that you don't have to do many of the steps related to SID change and it does make sense if you will be installing the instance temporarily. If your network cannot accommodate the unique hostname and SID and If you want to change hostname and sid please refer to other blog. Also if it is a more permanent installation you may like to change SID and hostname.

This Blog is based on a fresh installation of SUSE Linux for SAP OS without having any previous SAP instances created and deleted. I did not have to pre install hostagent, etc. There are mount points/links to be setup as shown in the right place in the directory structure. The steps in the guides provided with SAP Note 2041140 could be used as a reference in case there are issues specific to your environment. Just follow the steps below to install both systems shown in red square below:

Please find below the main note for ordering the appliance:
2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

PART1: SOFTWARE DOWNLOAD

Please download the software media from https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter
INSTALLATIONS & UPGRADES => By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) => S => SAP S/4HANA => SAP S/4HANA 2023 => S/4HANA FULLY-ACTIVATED APPLIANCE => SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 FA APPL

On SAP S/4HANA Server, download the 51058694_1 to 51058694_5  files and SWPM20SP22_3-80003424.SAR (or later).

On SAP NW JAVA / ADS server, download the 51058694_5, SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR and 51050829_JAVA_part 1 & 2 - NW 7.5 Java based SW Comp.

PART2: INSTALL SAP S/4HANA

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. For /sapmnt provide min 30GB, /hana/data space - min 500GB, /hana/log min 120GB. I have used /sapmedia - 200GB temporary separate mount that can be removed later.

TIP: The /sapmedia filesystem could be external mount. To save this space, the files could be downloaded to /hana/data/HDB and deleted as they are being extracted. In this case it would be good to extract dbdata files first.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES Extract files 51058694_*  in /sapmedia

sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_1.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_2.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_3.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_4.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_5.ZIP

Allow approx 2 hours for extraction.

We will install Central system with DB and App on same server. Please move all *.tgz-* files (from 51058694_1 to 51058694_4) to /sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1

cd /sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
mv /sapmedia/51058694_2/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_2/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_3/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_3/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_4/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_4/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_5/*.tgz-*   .

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

Please use command below to extract the database related archives:

sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia/# cd 51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
cat dblog.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

Similarly extract the remaining files:

cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

It takes about an hour for extraction.

Below two Application related archives may be extracted on a separate app server for distributed installation. These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/S4H and /usr/sap/S4H

Then extract the files:

cat sapmnt_s4h.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml

Follow this procedure as it is a known issue, please refer SAP Note 2082466 - Known Issues in SAP HANA Platform Lifecycle Management (HDBLCM)  (Issue# 69)

cd /hana/shared/HDB/HDB02/vhcalhdbdb
rm .daemon.ini.swp

vi daemon.ini
Edit section [localsecurestore] to change instances = 0

Execute HANA database specific steps as below:

https://sid-hdb-s4h.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

Click on Next.

Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Parameter you can change Schema User , DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM password. Please note it is also optional to change the schema user SAPHANADB password along with DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM users.

At the screen Database Schema accept schema SAPHANADB password and confirm Schema password Xxxxxxxn click on Next.

At the screen Rename Tenant Database click on Next

At the screen Secure Storage for Database Connection select HANA Secure User tore (hdbuserstore) click on Next

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Secure Storage Key Generation accept radio button – Individual Key (Recommended for Productive Systems) On the Next

At next screen Warning click OK

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next

At the above screen Keep Existing Licenses accept unchecked of Keep existing licenses. Click on Next

TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.
At next screen Cleanup of Encryption key checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

TIP: In case you get this ERROR:

RESOLUTION: Follow SAP Note 2800204 - SSFX-0362: Value file "-" does not start with the UTF-8 byte order mark

Ensure the environment variable LC_CTYPE of the user running sapinst is set as LC_CTYPE=en_US.
Stop the current sapinst and restart it. Continue with the existing option.

Then you can manually start the SAP instance S4H

sid-hdb-s4h:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StartSystem ALL

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder and remove temporary links to S4H.

Standard users are as follows:

Web Dispatcher access : bpinst/Welcome_2Welcome_2

STEP 7: Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf => Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Adapt HANA connections in DBACOCKPIT

Host name / port in table HTTPURLLOC

• S4H_RFC

entry.title: How to Assign Item Category to Material While Syncing to SAP CPQ – And Why It Matters
entry.content:
When integrating SAP CPQ (Configure, Price, Quote) with SAP S/4HANA or ERP, ECC, one critical step often overlooked is assigning the Item Category to materials during synchronization. This seemingly small detail plays a major role in ensuring smooth downstream processes like Sales Orders, Solution Quotations, and Solution Orders.

What is an Item Category ?

An Item Category in SAP determines how a material behaves in a document. It controls:

  • Whether the item is relevant for pricing.
  • If it requires a delivery or billing.
  • Whether it’s a service, a configurable product, or a standard material.
  • How it integrates with BOMs or solution components.

Reference Article/Blog explaining Item Categeory & group : Link

In short, the Item Category defines the business logic for the material in transactional documents.

Why Assign Item Category During Sync to SAP CPQ?

When materials are synced from SAP ERP to SAP CPQ, they carry essential attributes like material number, description, and pricing conditions. However, without the correct Item Category, CPQ cannot:

  • Determine if the material is a physical product, service, or text item.
  • Apply correct pricing and tax rules.
  • Generate accurate solution structures for complex configurations.

This impacts the integration when below are created:

  • Sales Orders: Applies for all ERP, S/4 HANA Public & Private Cloud
  • Solution Quotations: S/4 HANA Private Cloud or On-prem versions (Sales, Service & Subscription)
  • Solution Orders: S/4 HANA Public Cloud Edition (Sales, Service & Subscription)

Integration with SAP CPQ for Material Replication

SAP CPQ provides Product RestAPI to update itemcategorygroup for Materials..

Technical Note: Updating Item Category in SAP CPQ

SAP CPQ provides a Product REST API that allows you to update the itemCategory field for products. This is useful when you need to dynamically adjust item categories after initial synchronization or based on business rules.

  • Field: itemCategory
  • Purpose: Stores the ERP item category value or a mapped equivalent.
  • Usage: Can be updated via REST API calls for products in CPQ.

Integration Considerations

The standard SAP CPQ–SAP ERP/S4 HANA integration iFlow currently uses SOAP XML for material synchronization. This means:

  • Item category values from ERP cannot be included in the SOAP payload. (Help Doc)
  • If additional updates are needed post-sync, you can leverage the REST API for CPQ to patch the itemCategory field.

Conclusion:
Assigning the right Item Category during material sync to SAP CPQ is not just a technical step—it’s a business-critical process that ensures seamless integration, accurate pricing, and smooth execution of sales and solution orders.

entry.title: Article Discontinuation
entry.content:
Article Discontinuation – Business and Technical Overview

Article Discontinuation is a key step in an article’s lifecycle when the business decides that the product should no longer be carried. This decision can stem from several business scenarios, including:

Business Reasons for Article Discontinuation

  • Seasonal Fashion Items: Style cycles end and new season assortments are introduced.
  • End-of-Life Packaging Changes: Example: shifting from plastic bottles to eco-friendly recyclable packaging.
  • Model Upgrades in Electronics: Regular product refresh cycles.
  • Poor Sales Performance: Example: a slow-moving cereal brand removed by a grocery retailer.
  • Vendor Stops Supplying the Product.
  • Regulatory or Compliance Restrictions.
  • Short Shelf-Life or Expiry Constraints.
  • Assortment Rationalization / Space Optimization.
  • Product Safety Recalls.

Additionally, there are cases where an article is initially listed broadly for simplicity, but this creates technical issues later. In SAP Retail, listing is driven by general assortments, assortment modules, and listing conditions, and articles should only appear in sites belonging to their intended assortments. Incorrect assignments can cause unwanted listing propagation.

Business Impact of Incorrect Listing

  • Inaccurate stock availability displayed to store teams and online channels.
  • Unnecessary MRP proposals generated for all sites.
  • Incorrect data distributed to POS systems, causing clutter and possible cashier confusion.
  • Merchandising teams receive inaccurate assortment compliance reports.

Technical Impact

  • Unintended listing entries created in WLK1.
  • Additional footprints generated in tables such as MVKE, MARC, MBEW, etc.
  • POS outbound IDocs (WP_PLU) triggered for all sites.
  • Increased load on replenishment processing and EDI queues.
  • Incorrect inherited listing indicators in WRS1.
  • Business processes such as costing process unnecessary data, potentially affecting performance and increasing system footprint.

 Delisting vs. Discontinuation

Delisting (Removing Listing Conditions)

Delisting stops an article from being processed but does not remove the article master footprint.

Transaction codes for delisting:

  • WSP3 – Delete individual article listing conditions per distribution chain
  • WSE6 – Delete listing per assortment
  • Removing a site from an assortment using WSOA6 automatically delists all articles belonging to that site/assortment combination.

System behavior when an article is delisted:

  • Listing conditions are deleted automatically.
  • All listing entries (WLK1, WRS1, etc.) created through that assortment/module are removed.
  • The article master remains intact (MARA, MARC, MARD not deleted).
  • Existing stock remains visible and sellable.
  • MRP and procurement are blocked—no new POs/STOs will be created.
  • Sales may continue until on-hand stock reaches zero.

Article Discontinuation (Removing the Article Footprint)

To eliminate an article from the system, the process involves:

  1. Discontinuation – Sets the deletion indicator (LVORM)
  2. Archiving and Deletion – Executed via SARA (Object: MM_MATNR)

Discontinuation has far greater impact than delisting. When an article is discontinued:

  • The article master and all related data (purchasing info records, listing data, etc.) are marked for removal and eventually deleted through archiving.

Levels of Discontinuation

  • Client-wide
  • Supplier/Vendor
  • Plant/Site (includes distribution chain level)

Article Discontinuation Process in SAP Retail

  1. End listing conditions for the article using WSP3/WSE6/WSOA6.
  2. Trigger discontinuation using WRF_DIS_SEL (and monitor via WRF_DIS_MON).
  3. The discontinuation runs based on the Article Discontinuation Date—this must be after the ordering or sales block date.
  4. To run in background:
    • Deselect “Check material in full”
    • Select “Offline checks”

  1. Review the worklist in WRF_DIS_MON after job completion.
  2. If “Discontinue Immediately” is enabled and checks pass, SAP sets the deletion flag automatically.
  3. If issues exist, SAP lists them for manual resolution.
  4. Optional automated follow-up actions (e.g., transfer posting stock to a value-only article).
  5. Configuration: SPRO → Logistics General → Material Master → Retail Specific Settings → Settings for Material Discontinuation
  6. Once LVORM is set → Archive and delete via SARA (MM_MATNR).

Useful Information & Tools

Set deletion flags at Sales Org/Distribution Channel level

Use standard report RWSORT41MVKE
Key fields:

  • AUF_SAM: Explode generic material
  • P_TEST: Test mode
  • S_MATKL: Article Group
  • S_MATNR: Article
  • S_VKORG: Sales Organization
  • S_VTWEG: Distribution Channel

Mass Discontinuation for All Articles at a Site

  • Enter wildcard (*) for article in WRF_DIS_SEL
  • Enter target plant/site under Plant Data
  • Note: This selects all MARC records for that site—evaluate volume before execution.

Reset Deletion Flag

Use WSE8

Important Limitations

  • Discontinuation indicators in MARA/MARC cannot be set using BAPIs or IDocs. Only WRF_DIS_SEL supports this process.

entry.title: Introducing User-Defined Reports (UDR) in SAP Responsible Production and Design
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of SAP Responsible Design and Production as of November 25, 2025.

SAP Responsible Design and Production released User-Defined Reports (UDR) this year, extending its reporting framework with a fully configurable, customer-driven approach developed to support customers with the ever-evolving and growing number of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) regulations. With UDR, users can now create customized EPR reports for packaging based on their unique business and compliance needs.

UDR also enables SAP and in the near future, content partners, to offer templates for new EPR schemes that customers can adapt in their own systems, to help them expand EPR reporting quickly. This new functionality aims to ease the burden of managing reporting obligations across multiple markets.

This blog post explains the background and motivation for this feature, provides a sneak peek into the key functionalities used to create country-specific EPR report categories, and highlights how this enhancement improves flexibility and extensibility for EPR data reporting.

Background

As EPR regulations continue to expand globally, businesses face increasing complexity in how they manage compliance. Regulations vary not only from country to country but often overlap or undergo changes over time, making it challenging for customers to keep up while relying on predefined reporting structures.

SAP Responsible Design and Production has long supported customers in meeting EPR requirements through SAP-provided report categories that are preconfigured to match the packaging obligations in countries such as Spain, Italy, and the UK. While these reports have served as a reliable foundation, there is a growing need for a more flexible and more nuanced reporting approach.

Companies increasingly require a way to:

  • Adapt quickly to new or changing legislation
  • Reuse rules and fee structures across similar reporting schemes or Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs)
  • Consolidate data from diverse sources
  • Customize reporting logic based on their specific business context

This is exactly why SAP introduced User-Defined Reports (UDR): to provide customers with an agile, scalable, and future-ready foundation for building report categories aligned with regulatory logic, business context, and compliance requirements.

Key Capabilities of UDR

User-Defined Reports bring together several powerful capabilities that allow customers to design report categories tailored to their specific regulatory and operational needs. 

1 Build the Structure of Your Report

Responsible Organizations

EPR schemes are managed by Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs). Many countries operate with more than one PRO, each offering different fee structures or criteria. In Spain, for example, Ecoembes manages general packaging, while Ecovidrio is responsible for glass packaging. UDR allows users to:

  • Attach multiple PRO-specific fee tables to the same report category
  • Reuse the same report fractions and rules across PROs
  • Avoid creating separate report categories for each PRO (as long as their rules do not conflict)

This gives customers flexibility in markets where several PROs coexist.

Report Fractions

Report fractions are the foundational building blocks of a UDR report. They represent the categories into which packaging is classified according to national legislation or PRO requirements. Fractions can be created and named based on the exact fee structure of the country or PRO, ensuring a one-to-one alignment with how fees are calculated.

Report Fraction Groups

To support cleaner structuring and reporting layouts, fractions can be combined into report fraction groups. These groups help users organize related fractions (for example, separating paper-related fractions based on usage or the brand) and simplify both calculation and reporting outputs.

2 Control the Logic Behind Your Report

Filters for Included Packaging

Filters add a foundational layer of control by allowing users to exclude packaging that should not be part of a particular report or fee calculation. They can be applied at multiple levels within the report category setup and help ensure that only relevant data is included based on the requirements of each EPR scheme.

Together with calculation rules, filters help shape a reporting outcome that aligns with legislative and business requirements.

Calculation Rules

Report calculation rules form one of the most powerful elements of UDR.
They determine which packaging is included in a report and how quantities and fees are calculated, giving customers the flexibility to reflect the exact compliance logic required by each market. Because calculation rules can combine multiple conditions, attributes, and data sources, they enable users to shape reporting logic precisely around their business and regulatory needs, making this capability central to the flexibility that UDR offers.

Calculation rules come with a wide collection of rule examples, expressions and functions that can be leveraged to fit the users’ reporting requirements.

Logistic Processes

Logistic processes represent the specific movements of products or packaging that are relevant for a country’s EPR legislation, such as domestic sales, imports, exports, or other flows defined by the market. In UDR, users can select which logistic processes apply to their report category and combine them with filters or calculation rules. This allows the user to reflect only the movements that are obligated in that country, ensuring the report aligns with how packaging enters or leaves the market.

 

3 Capture Sustainability-Driven Criteria

Ecomodulation

Many EPR schemes increasingly use ecomodulation to reward sustainable packaging choices. UDR allows users to set ecomodulation criteria based on the relevant EPR scheme and incorporate them into calculation rules. This further enables fees to be calculated according to the required ecomodulation rules. To learn more about ecomodulation, visit the SAP Responsible Design and Production community page for a detailed blog on this topic, releasing soon.

Recyclability

UDR also integrates recyclability outcomes directly into reports. When setting up a report, recyclability guidelines can be selected and applied, to be used in calculation rules when needed. This allows recyclability insights to feed directly into the report structure, supporting countries where recyclability affects fees or criteria (such as the bonus/malus payments on EPR fees in France). Users can either upload date manually via Excel or integrate with a partner of their choice.

4 Test and Validate Your Setup

Test Configuration

With test configurations, users can simulate the reporting outcome for one to ten products. This enables quick validation of rule logic, filters, and fee calculations before generating the full report, ensuring accuracy and reducing iteration time.

5 Templates

Not all EPR schemes have the same level of complexity. To ease the effort in building highly detailed report categories using UDR, Templates have been introduced; preconfigured starter packs that provide the structure and logic needed to get started, which can be adapted to fit the user’s requirements.

Currently, SAP provides Templates for US-Colorado, US-Oregon, and Denmark, with more to follow. Keep an eye on the SAP Responsible Design and Production Roadmap for upcoming additions.

Customer Response & Early Results

Customers who tested UDR shared strong and practical feedback, including:

“Only 25% of time and effort is required for using UDR compared to manual efforts.” (from consumer products company)

“First we were skeptic, but now we like using UDR.” (from food processing company)

These early insights reflect the impact of a flexible, user-driven reporting approach. To see this in a real-world setting, please check out our recent webinar, Navigating EPR regulations in the United States: Act Now! where our customer shares their experience with UDR.

What’s Next

UDR was shaped with direct input from customers, and this collaboration will continue. As EPR regulations evolve, SAP will focus on enhancing UDR, improving the configuration experience, and supporting reporting needs across markets.

One of the planned enhancements is around AI-assisted features that could make it easier to create calculation rules logic and work more efficiently with UDR using natural language.

Where to Learn More and Act!

To further explore UDR, detailed documentation with practical examples and additional guidance on calculation rules  available. You can also access a guided, step-by-step walkthrough showing how to create a UDR here.  We will continue to publish updates there as UDR evolves.

For broader product information on SAP Responsible Design and Production, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release. 

To take the next step, you can request a demo or contact us for a consultation. For additional regulatory context and practical guidance, you may also want to download our white paper on managing EPR regulations and plastic taxes.

entry.title: The Secure Way to Migrate S/4HANA: Step-by-Step HANA Tenant Copy with SSL Encryption
entry.content:
As customers rapidly migrate S/4HANA systems to Private Cloud environments (Azure, AWS, GCP, SAP RISE), they often choose an "as-is" migration. This decouples functional upgrades from the technical move, significantly compressing project duration and minimizing the need for extensive regression testing.

While traditional methods like HANA Backup/Restore (only viable for small databases) and HANA System Replication (HSR) are common, HSR presents critical challenges in a cloud migration:

  1. Homogeneous Naming: HSR demands the same SID and Instance Number for source and target, which conflicts with new naming conventions often required on the cloud, especially in SAP RISE.
  2. Auxiliary Usage: Using the HA/DR focused HSR solution for a one-time copy complicates the reconfiguration of the target HA/DR setup after cutover.
  3. Cutover Time: Breaking replication and re-establishing HA/DR post-cutover adds additional downtime.

HANA Tenant Copy: The Migration Alternative

HANA Tenant Copy is an ECS-supported approach that addresses these HSR limitations. While operationally somewhat to HSR, it differs conceptually and is suitable for migrating systems that require a SID change on the target. It creates an isolated replica of any tenant, requiring mostly that the target HANA version is same or higher than the source.

🔐Securing the Tenant Copy Data Transfer (SSL)

A crucial security requirement is ensuring the data transfer between source and target is secure via SSL. Most Basis teams overlook this, thinking it requires external certificates. However, we can easily achieve this using the inbuilt certificate every HANA DB already possesses. In this post, we are going to see how we can 

Pre-Requisite –

Set-up below parameters on Source and Target Database. Also, log mode should be normal for Tenant Copy to work.

Verify the SYSTEM layer values of the following parameters in the global.ini file:

  • [communication] ssl must be set to systempki
  • [system_replication_communication] enable_ssl must be set to on

On Source DB only –

Verify the SYSTEM layer values of the following parameters in the global.ini file:

  • [communication] listeninterface must be set to .global

(A DB restart would be required in most cases).

When establishing connectivity between the Source and Target databases, the following port ranges should be opened. If security policies are restrictive, specific ports based on the instance number can be opened instead.

Port Range

Purpose

3XXXX

Mandatory. SQL port of the HANA Index Server. Main port used by application servers and SQL clients to connect to the HANA DB.

4XXXX

Mandatory. Internal HANA communication port, used heavily for system replication (HSR) and Tenant Copy.

5XXXX

Recommended. Used by nameserver, web dispatcher–related connections, and certain internal HA/scale-out services. Helps hosts exchange availability and topology information.

 Step-by-Step Secure Tenant Copy Execution

Step1: Create a dummy Tenant Database (ABC) on the source system to serve as a copy template. (Note: For actual migration, use the existing S/4HANA connected database, skipping this creation step.)

Take backup of the source database so that Tenant copy can be initiated (same restriction as that of HSR)

Step 2: On the target HANA system, create a Personal Security Environment (PSE) (e.g., TenantCopy) and assign its purpose as Database Replication.

Step 3: On the source HANA system, navigate to the $SECUDIR directory and copy the content of the root certificate, which is typically named clientpki_SYSTEMDB.cer. (Important: Use the SYSTEMDB certificate, not the tenant's certificate like clientpki_ABC.cer).

Step 4: Using the copied certificate content, create a new certificate entity within the target HANA database.

Step 5 : On the target system, execute the necessary SQL query to identify and note the certificate number assigned to the new certificate created in Step 4.

Step 6 : Add the certificate identified in Step 5 to the PSE created in Step 2 on the target system.

Step 7: Verify the successful addition by querying the PSE_CERTIFICATE view on the target HANA system.

Step 8: On the target system, create a Credential for the source database, using the Source SYSTEMDB password for authentication.

Step 9: On the Target, initiate the Replica Query to copy the source tenant (ABC) to the target tenant (XYZ). (In a real scenario, you would first stop the target Application Server, drop the existing S/4HANA target DB, and then create the new tenant with the exact required target name.).

Step 10 : Monitor the replication from the Target. Replication is active when the status shows Target_Active_Status = “Yes”. The replication is complete when the DB status in M_DATABASE changes to ACTIVE REPLICA, indicating the target is ready for finalization.

 

Step 11: On the target system, issue the Finalize Replica Query to bring the target database online. (Crucially, before executing the finalization, stop the source S/4HANA system to mark the business downtime start.)

After finalization, perform follow-up activities, including reconfiguring the HDBUSERSTORE and starting the target S/4HANA application system.

References –

Copying and Moving Tenant Databases | SAP Help Portal

Copy or Move Tenants Within System Replication | SAP Help Portal

 

Best Regards,

Javed Alam

SAP BASIS Technical Architect

entry.title: SAP EWM Labor Management (Engineered Labor Standards)
entry.content:
SAP EWM Labor Management is designed to help warehouses gain clear visibility into how efficiently work is performed on the floor. It enables businesses to define labor standards, track planned versus actual execution times, and measure processor performance for different warehouse activities. These standards can be based on various operational parameters such as weight, quantity, product attributes, or activity type, allowing flexible modeling of real-world scenarios. The functionality also supports tracking of both direct tasks and indirect labor efforts, giving a complete picture of workforce utilization. This blog focuses on demonstrating how engineering labor standards work within SAP EWM.

Configurations

1. Activate BC Sets:

T.code: SCPR20

To enable SAP EWM Labor Management (LM) functionality, SAP provides several LM-specific BC Sets. These BC Sets deliver predefined configuration content that supports various LM capabilities such as activity definitions, engineered labor standards, exception codes, performance measurement, and warehouse-level settings.

  • /SCWM/LM
  • /SCWM/LM_ACTIVITY
  • /SCWM/LM_ELS
  • /SCWM/LM_EXCEPTION_CODES
  • /SCWM/LM_EXTERNAL_PROCESS_STEPS
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_EPD
  • /SCWM/LM_NR_INDIRECT_LABOR_TASK
  • /SCWM/LM_PLAN_AREA
  • /SCWM/LM_PREPROCESSING
  • /SCWM/LM_WHS_NUMBER
  • /SCWM/PRC_LM_10
  • /SCWM/PRC_LM_15

2. Activate Labor Management
Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Activate Labor Management

3. Define External Process steps

6. Define Number Range for Performance Document

Path : SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define Number Range for Performance Document

7. Define Delivery Date/Time for Preprocessing

Path: SAP Customizing Implementation Guide -> SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Labor Management -> Define Delivery Date/Time for Preprocessing

8. Activate Change Documents in Labor Management

  • Activate Change Documents for Processor
